intro: Abelia spathulata var. elliptica, commonly known as the elliptic abelia, is a deciduous shrub native to China. It features narrow, elliptical leaves that are typically dark green on top and lighter underneath. The plant produces clusters of fragrant, white to pink flowers in late spring to early summer. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained soil. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and adaptability to various garden conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abelia spathulata var. elliptica is primarily native to eastern North America, specifically the southeastern United States. It is found in states such as Georgia, Florida, Alabama, and South Carolina. This plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils along stream banks and in woodland areas. It thrives in partial to full shade and is often found in the understory of forests. Its native range includes the coastal plain and piedmont regions of the southeastern U.S.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abelia spathulata var. elliptica was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It is commonly found in moist, well-drained soils in shaded to partially sunny environments. This plant is often used in landscaping for its attractive, fragrant flowers and ornamental value. It has been reported in both cultivated gardens and naturalized areas. However, it is considered a non-native species and may have potential ecological impacts in certain regions.
